statement.tex: %text To raise money for an orphanage. students of three schools $A$, $B$ and $C$ organised an exhibition in their locality, where they sold paper bags, scrap-books and pastel sheets made by them using recycled paper, at the rate of $₹ 20$, $₹ 15$ and $₹ 5$ per unit respectively. School $A$ sold $25$ paper bags, $12$ scrap-books and $34$ pastel sheets. School $B$ sold $22$ paper bags, $15$ scrap-books and $28$ pastel sheets while School $C$ sold $26$ paper bags $18$ scrap-books and $36$ pastel sheets. Using matrices, find the total amount raised by each school. %

reason.tex: %text Basic reasoning here, nothing specific, Quantity (units)$\times$ Rate (₹/unit) $=$ A(₹) %

%text There exist a $3\times 3$ Quantity matrix and a $1\times 3$ Amount matrix. We know that $Q\times R=A$. We have $3$ rates, therefore the Rate matrix can be set up either as a $1\times 3$ or a $3\times 1$. As per rules of matrix multiplication, % \begin{align} \begin{array}{ccc} \hline \text{Matrix A} & \text{Matrix B} & A\times B \\ \hline [3\times 3] & [3\times 1] & [3\times 1] \\ [3\times 3] & [1\times 3] & \text{N/A} \end{array} \end{align} \\ %text In $3\times 1$ configuration, the total amounts raised by each school would be realised correctly as the weighted sum of the amounts raised for each good type. %

%text Each item in a row of the quantity matrix multiplies with the appropriate rate from rate matrix. When added together, these products represent the total amount raised by a school. Therefore, % \begin{align} \left[\begin{array}{ccc} 25 & 12 & 34 \\ 22 & 15 & 28 \\ 26 & 18 & 36 \end{array}\right]\times \left[\begin{array}{c} 20 \\ 15 \\ 5 \end{array}\right]=\left[A_1 \quad A_2\quad A_3\right]\, \end{align} \\ \text{Where,} \\ \begin{align} A_1=(25\times 20+12\times 15+34\times 5)=₹850 \\ A_2=(22\times 20+15\times 15+28\times 5)=₹805 \\ A_3=(26\times 20+18\times 15+36\times 5)=₹970 \\ \end{align}
